raw_text:
Gadget market 'to grow in 2005'
 
 The explosion in consumer technology is to continue into 2005, delegates at the world's largest gadget show, in Las Vegas, have been told.
 
 The number of gadgets in the shops is predicted to grow by 11%, while devices which talk to each other will become increasingly important. "Everything is going digital," Kirsten Pfeifer from the Consumer Electronics Association, told the BBC News website. The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) featured the pick of 2005's products. "Consumers are controlling what they want and technologies like HDTVs [high-definition TVs], digital radio, and digital cameras will remain strong in 2005. "All the products on show really showed the breadth and depth of the industry." Despite showing diversity, some delegates attending complained that the showcase lacked as much "wow factor" as in previous years.
 
 The portable technologies on show also reflected one of the buzzwords of CES, which was the "time and place shifting" of multimedia content - being able to watch and listen to video and music anywhere, at any time. At the start of last year's CES, the CEA predicted there would be an average growth of 4% in 2004. That figure was surpassed with the rise in popularity of portable digital music players, personal video recorders and digital cameras. It was clear also that gadgets are becoming a lot more about lifestyle choice, with fashion and personalisation becoming increasingly key to the way gadgets are designed. Part of this has been the rise in spending power of the "generation X-ers" who have grown up with technology and who now have the spending power and desire for more devices that suit them. More than 57% of the consumer electronics market is made up of female buyers, according to CEA research. Hybrid devices, which combine a number of multimedia functions, were also in evidence on the show floor. "A lot of this is driven by just the ability to do it," said Stephen Baker, a consumer electronics analyst with retail research firm NPD Group. "Some of these functions cost next to nothing to add."
 
 As well as the show floor showcasing everything from tiny wearable MP3 players to giant high-definition TVs, several keynote speeches were made by industry leaders, such as Microsoft chief Bill Gates. Despite several embarrassing technical glitches during Mr Gate's pre-show speech, he announced several new partnerships - mainly for the US market. He unveiled new ways of letting people take TV shows recorded on personal video recorders and watch them back on portable devices. He disappointed some, however, by failing to announce any details of the next generation of the Xbox games console. Another disappointment was the lack of exposure Sony's new portable games device, the PSP, had at the show. Sony said the much-anticipated gadget would most likely start shipping in March for the US and Europe. It went on sale in Japan before Christmas. There were only two PSPs embedded in glass cabinets at the show though and no representatives to discuss further details. A Sony representative told the BBC News website this was because Sony did not consider it to be part of their "consumer technology" offering.
 
 Elsewhere at the show, there was a plethora of colour and plasma screens, including Samsung's 102-inch (2.6 metre) plasma - the largest in the world. Industry experts were also excited about high-definition technologies coming to the fore in 2005, with new formats for DVDs coming out which will hold six times as much data as conventional DVDs. With so many devices on the move there were a lot of products on show offering external storage, like Seagate's 5GB pocket sized external hard drive, which won an innovation for engineering and design prize. More than 120,000 trade professionals attended CES in Las Vegas, which officially ran from 6 to 9 January.
llama3.2:1b: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas is expected to see a 11% growth in gadget sales in 2005. The industry will feature increased importance of devices that talk to each other and high-definition technologies. Personal video recorders, digital cameras, and portable digital music players are popular products on display. Hybrid devices with multiple multimedia functions also emerge as key market trends.
llama3.2:3b: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) predicted the gadget market to grow by 11% in 2005, with devices that talk to each other becoming increasingly important. The show featured diverse products including HDTVs, digital cameras and portable technologies, showcasing "time and place shifting" of multimedia content. Hybrid devices and fashion became key aspects of gadget design, driven by the growing spending power of Generation X-ers. Industry leaders made keynote speeches, with Microsoft's Bill Gates announcing new partnerships but disappointing some with no details on the next Xbox console.
gemma2:2b: The gadget market is expected to grow significantly in 2005, with increased consumer demand for digital products like HDTVs, digital radio, and digital cameras. Portable technologies are central to this growth, with "time and place shifting" of multimedia content being a key trend.  Lifestyle choice is emphasized, with gadgets becoming more personalized and fashion-forward. The market is driven by both existing technology features and new innovations, as seen in hybrid devices, external storage options, and advanced screen technologies. Keynotes from industry leaders like Bill Gates highlighted the growing focus on consumer interaction and access to content.   However, some major releases, such as Sony's PSP, received limited exposure, sparking speculation about their overall impact on the market.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Gadget markets are expected to expand in 2005. The show features new devices like portable digital music players, personal video recorders and cameras that become increasingly popular as they compete with high-definition TVs and HDTVs. Consumers' preferences for mobile technologies such as smartphones and tablets also increase. Gadget developers focus on functionality rather than aesthetics, especially with consumer electronics. Tech companies are investing heavily in new product development.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas predicts a 11% increase in gadgets sales in 2005 with high-definition TVs, digital radio, and cameras becoming increasingly important. The show features diverse products showcasing the industry's breadth and depth. Despite complaints about lack of "wow factor", spending power of "generation X-ers" drives growth in portable devices like MP3 players and video recorders. Sony's new game device is delayed due to insufficient exposure at the show.
qwen2.5:3b: Gadget market is expected to grow by 11% in 2005, with digital technologies such as HDTVs, digital radio, and cameras remaining strong. The Consumer Electronics Show showcased diverse products reflecting the "time and place shifting" of multimedia content, including portable devices like digital music players, personal video recorders, and cameras. Fashion and personalisation are increasingly important in gadget design, driven by spending power among Generation X consumers. Hybrid devices combining multiple functions are popular. Industry leaders like Microsoft and Sony made keynote speeches. Keynote speakers highlighted new technologies such as ways to access TV shows on portable devices and advancements in high-definition DVDs. The show featured a wide range of products including external storage solutions and large-screen displays. Over 120,000 professionals attended the event from January 6-9.

Despite showcasing diversity, some attendees complain about lack of "wow factor" compared to previous years. deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about the gadget market growing into 2005. Let me start by reading through it carefully and picking out the main points.

First, they mention that there's an explosion in consumer technology, specifically at the CES show in Las Vegas. The number of gadgets is expected to grow by 11% in 2005. They also talk about devices talking to each other becoming more important, which probably means connectivity between devices is increasing.

The Consumer Electronics Association (CEA) said things like HDTVs, digital radio, and digital cameras will remain strong in 2005. So, they're still going to be big parts of the market despite some changes. However, consumers have control over what they want, which means there's more choice than before.

There are complaints about the show lacking a "wow factor" compared to previous years. Maybe that refers to how exciting or attention-grabbing the products were this year? That might be something for future talks or media coverage.

 Portable technologies on display include things like digital music players, video recorders, and digital cameras. They mentioned the rise in spending power of Gen X-ers, who are tech-savvy adults now. More than 57% of consumers bought electronic gadgets in 2004, which is more female buyers. Hybrid devices were also shown.

Stephen Baker from NPD Group noted that spending on these devices can be driven by their ability to do things without extra cost. He mentioned partnerships like Microsoft and Sony with the Xbox games console, but those details didn't come up for the next generation yet. Sony has a PSP device scheduled for sale in Japan before Christmas and in March for the US market.

They also talked about other gadgets like color and plasma screens from Samsung. High-definition data formats like DVDs are expanding, holding more data than traditional ones. There's a lot of external storage products like Seagate's 5GB drive mentioned, which has an engineering design prize. The CES had over 120k trade professionals, with the show running from January 6th to 9th.

Wait, I need to make sure I'm capturing all key points without losing any important details. Maybe I can group them into sectors like consumer electronics growth, connectivity, choice among consumers, spending power of tech users, partnerships and hardware trends, display features, data formats, external storage, and event details.

Putting it all together into a concise summary that includes these aspects should cover the main points without being too verbose.
</think>

The gadget market is expected to grow in 2005 at CES in Las Vegas. Key points include rising device diversity, increased connectivity (e.g., HDTVs, digital radio, digital cameras) and devices interacting with each other.消费者选择性增强，消费能力提升，尤其是Gen X-ers。消费占73%的市场，女性占比57%，多设备类型如移动音乐、视频记录器、摄像头展示。 Microsoft与 Sony 携带=xbox console 外卖机会，而 Sony 的 PSP 未上市。展览展示了大量高分辨率技术，包括102英寸 plasma 等大屏幕。
tinyllama:1.1b: The explosion of consumer technology is expected to continue into 2005 with the growth of devices such as digital cameras, digital TVs, and digital radios, according to the keynote speeches made by industry leaders during CEA's Consumer Electronics Show. The Consumer Electronics Association (CEA) predicts that every product on show will remain strong in 2005. One of the buzzwords for 2004 was "time and place shift," as multimedia content can now be watched and listened to anywhere, anytime. Keynote speeches from industry leaders like Microsoft CEO Bill Gatees and Sony representative stated that consuming multimedia content has never been easier, but there were still some technical glitches during Mr. Gate's pre-show speech. Despite several embarrassing technical glitches, the Consumer Electronics Show featured a plethora of color and plasmascreens, including Samsonng's 102-inch (2.6 metre) plasmascreen. External hard drives like SeaGate's 5GB pocket sized external hard drive were also showcased at the show, proving to be innovative in their engineering and design. As for what consumers can expect in 2005, a plethora of devices are expected to offer greater levels of multimedia functionality, including digital cameras and televisions.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Summarizing the text: "The Gadget Market is expected to grow by a massive 11% in 2005, according to experts at the world's largest gadget show. New innovations like portable digital music players, personal video recorders, and high-definition TVs are set to dominate the market, as consumers continue to control their technology with ease."
phi:2.7b: The CES gadget market is predicted to grow by 11% in 2005 as consumers take control of what they want from technology like HDTVs, digital radio, and cameras. Portable technologies will become increasingly important for time-shifting multimedia content. A variety of hybrid devices that combine multiple functions are also becoming popular. Despite the rise in popularity of portable devices, some attendees at CES felt there was a lack of excitement in the showcase compared to previous years. The event featured products showcasing diversity and personalisation while catering to female buyers who make up more than 57% of the consumer electronics market. Microsoft's Bill Gates announced new partnerships for the US market, including ways to watch TV shows recorded on personal video recorders on portable devices. However, some were disappointed by the lack of announcements about Xbox's next generation games console and Sony's PSP. Despite this, there was excitement in the industry about high-definition technologies coming to the forefront with the release of new DVD formats that can hold six times as much data as conventional DVDs. The show also featured a plethora of screens, including Samsung' s 102-inch plasma screen, the largest in the world, and external storage options like Seagate' s 5GB pocket sized external hard drive, which won an innovation for engineering and design prize.
orca-mini:3b: The gadget market is expected to grow by 11% in 2005, according to delegates at the world's largest gadget show held in Las Vegas. Portable technologies were a key focus, with consumers wanting to watch and listen to video and music anywhere, at any time. Hybrid devices combining multimedia functions were also on display. Despite complaints about the lack of "wow factor" in previous years, some designers showcased their latest products. Microsoft's Bill Gates announced several new partnerships for the US market, but no details were revealed of the next generation of the Xbox games console. Sony's portable games device, the PSP, had limited exposure at the show. Despite the largest plasma screen on display, there was a focus on HD technologies coming out in 2005. The Consumer Electronics Association predicted an increase in spending power for female buyers, with more than 57% of the market made up by them. Attendees were excited about high-definition technologies and colour and plasma screens, including Samsung's 102-inch (2.6 metre) plasma. Designers won innovation prizes for their work on engineering and technology.
hermes3:3b: Gadget market predicted to grow by 11% in 2005. Digital devices, lifestyle choice, and multimedia content shifting expected to be major trends.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Gadget market growth is predicted to continue into 2005, with 11% increase in available products and an increased focus on devices that interact with each other. The Consumer Electronics Show showcased the top products of the year, featuring time and place shifting multimedia content, hybrid devices combining multiple functions, and a greater emphasis on fashion and personalization. Industry leaders announced new partnerships, but missed opportunities included the lack of exposure for Sony's portable games device, the PSP. High-definition technologies are expected to become more prominent in 2005, with improved DVD formats holding six times as much data as conventional discs.

Key trends include the continued popularity of HDTVs, digital radios, and cameras, as well as the rise of portable technologies enabling media consumption anywhere. The market is also being shaped by lifestyle preferences, with fashion and personalization playing a larger role, and female buyers making up 57% of the consumer electronics market. Hybrid devices combining multiple functions are becoming more common due to low additional costs. 

Industry leaders, including Microsoft’s Bill Gates, made keynote speeches, though his presentation was marred by technical glitches. He announced new partnerships and TV-to-portable device integration but did not reveal details about the next Xbox. Sony’s PSP had limited presence at the show, with no representatives available for discussion. Other highlights included Samsung’s 102-inch plasma screen, advancements in high-definition technology, and new high-capacity DVD formats. External storage solutions, such as Seagate’s 5GB pocket-sized hard drive, also gained attention. The event attracted over 120,000 trade professionals from January 6-9.

Microsoft CEO Bill Gates delivered several keynote speeches at the event, revealing new partnerships and product releases. However, Sony's PSP portable games device received little attention due to its exclusion from the show floor, despite being available in Japan beforehand.
